edge: A movie is represented by its summary, which provides a brief overview of the plot and characters in the movie.

The film and novel share the same title as they both focus on exposing the challenges faced by African American people during the Civil Rights Movement through the perspectives of black domestic workers, referred to as 'the help'.
Both terms refer to the protagonist of the story, a young white woman and aspiring journalist who decides to write a book from the point of view of black maids during the Civil Rights Movement.
Both terms refer to two black maids who work for white families and are portrayed in the story. Their experiences and perspectives on race relations during the Civil Rights Movement are explored.
Both terms refer to the historical context in which the story takes place, a significant period of social and political change for African Americans.
Both terms refer to locations where the story is set, with Jackson being a city in Mississippi and Madison being a suburb of it.

node_2: producers chris columbus, michael barnathan, and brunson green
edge: Both terms refer to the production company that acquired the screen rights to Kathryn Stockett's novel and produced the film. Chris Columbus, Michael Barnathan, and Brunson Green are the producers of the film.

Skeeter writes a book titled 'The Help' about the experiences of African American maids in Jackson. This leads to controversy and backlash from some of the white women in the city.
Skeeter's boyfriend Stuart realizes she wrote 'The Help' and breaks up with her.
Minny subtly reveals the 'terrible awful' to Celia, calling her 'Two Slice Hilly'.
Hilly threatens to sue Skeeter for libel over 'The Help', but backs down when she realizes the implications.
Aibileen's congregation honors her for her leadership in the publication of 'The Help'.
Johnny promises Minny permanent job security and assures her that she can leave her abusive husband.
As Aibileen is leaving, she begs Elizabeth to love her daughter who's crying for her.
Hilly pressures Elizabeth to fire Aibleen by claiming that she has stolen silverware.
As Aibleen is leaving, she decides to quit domestic work and become a writer instead.
Greenwood was chosen to portray 1960s-era Jackson in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Emma Stone was attached to play the role of Eugenia 'Skeeter' Phelan in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Viola Davis played the role of Aibileen in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Bryce Dallas Howard played the role of Hilly Holbrook, a racist and town ringleader in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Allison Janney played the role of Charlotte Phelan, Skeeter's mother in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Chris Lowell played the character of Stuart Whitworth, Skeeter's boyfriend and a senator's son in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Leslie Jordan appeared as the editor of the fictional local newspaper, The Jackson Journal in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Mike Vogel played the character Johnny Foote in the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Octavia Spencer portrayed Minny, a character based on her own life experiences, in both the book and the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
Parts of the film were also shot in the real-life city of Clarksdale, Mississippi.
Other locations that can still be found in Jackson include Greenville, which was also used as a filming location for the movie.
Tate Taylor wrote, directed, and co-produced the film adaptation of 'The Help'.
DreamWorks obtained the film rights to the book before its publication.
Reliance Entertainment co-produced the film adaptation of 'The Help' in collaboration with Participant Media.
Brent's Drugs is a real location in the book and film that dates back to 1946. It still exists in Jackson, Mississippi.
The New Capitol Building is a real location that can still be found in Jackson, Mississippi and was mentioned in the book and film.
The Mayflower Cafe is a real location that can still be found downtown in Jackson, Mississippi and was mentioned in the book and film.

In the film adaptation of The Help, scenes set at the Jackson Journal office were shot in Clarksdale at the building which formerly housed the Clarksdale Press Register for forty years until April 2010.

To convince producers to shoot in Greenwood, Tate Taylor and others came to the town and scouted locations. At his first meeting with DreamWorks executives, he presented them with a photo album of potential filming spots in the area.
The Help was the most significant film production in Mississippi since O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000). The state's tax incentive program for filmmakers was a key enticement in the decision.
Two soundtracks were released for The Help: an original soundtrack and an original score. The state's tax incentive program for filmmakers was a key enticement in the decision.

Two soundtracks were released for The Help: an original soundtrack and an original score. As a collective, the songs spotlight the peak of the fight for equality in the United States during the civil rights movement.
The soundtrack album for The Help, released by Geffen Records on August 4, 2011, features songs from the likes of Johnny Cash, Frankie Valli and Ray Charles.
The civil rights movement and Mississippi are connected as The Help's soundtrack album showcases songs from the peak of the fight for equality in the United States during this time period.

The digital download version of 'The Help' includes a deleted scene featuring Mary J. Blige.
On its opening day, 'The Help' grossed $5.54 million in North America.
'The Help' topped the box office charts for three consecutive weekends on its fourth weekend, which was a Labor Day weekend.
'The Help' crossed the $100 million mark on its 21st day of release in August 2011.

Tom Long from The Detroit News remarked about the film: "Appealing, entertaining, touching and perhaps even a bit healing, The Help is an old-fashioned grand yarn of a film, the sort we rarely get these days." CinemaScore polls reported that the average grade moviegoers gave the film was a rare 'A+' on an A+ to F scale.

[43] Metacritic, a review aggregator which assigns a weighted average score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, gives the film a score of 62 based on 41 reviews Indicating generally favorable reviews.

critical consensus reads: "Though arguably guilty of glossing over its racial themes, The Help rises on the strength of its cast – particularly Viola Davis, whose performance is powerful enough to carry the film on its own."[43]

Connie Ogle of Miami Herald gave the film three out of four stars and said it "will make you laugh, yes, but it can also break your heart. In the dog days of August moviegoing, that's a powerful recommendation."[47]
Referring to the film as a "big, ole slab of honey-glazed",.
The New York Times referred to The Help as a 'big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum'.
Some criticisms of the film accused its performances as 'almost all overly broad, sometimes excruciatingly so, characterized by loud laughs, bugging eyes and pumping limbs.'
Critics praised Viola Davis' performance in The Help, with David Edelstein commenting, 'The Help belongs to Viola Davis.'
Morales of Blackfilm.com commented, 'With powerful performances given by Viola Davis and scene stealer Octavia Spencer, the film is an emotionally moving drama that remains highly entertaining.'

Critics accused The Help of distorting, ignoring, and trivializing the experiences of black domestic workers, as stated by Ida E. Jones, national director of the Association of Black Women Historians.
The film focuses on maids during the Civil Rights Movement in 1963.

The film brings light to Medgar Evers, an African-American activist and NAACP leader, who worked toward gaining rights for African-Americans at the time, as well as aiding in the fight to end segregation. In the film, Skeeter and the two maids are seen watching Evers' address.
The ABWH accused both the book and the film of insensitive portrayals of African-American vernacular.

node_2: nearly uniform depiction of black men as cruel or absent
edge: The ABWH accused both the book and the film of a nearly uniform depiction of black men as cruel or absent.
Roxane Gay of literary web magazine The Rumpus argues the film might be offensive to African Americans, saying the film uses racial Hollywood tropes like the Magical Negro character.

node_2: academy award for best supporting actress
edge: At the 84th Academy Awards, Octavia Spencer won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in this film.
The film also received three other Academy Award nominations: Academy Award for Best Picture, Academy Award for Best Actress for Viola Davis,
